Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Chan meets the residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Mr. Chan was absent from Canada for 647 days due to caring for his ill mother in Hong Kong
Court_Ruling: Mr. Chan meets the residency requirement
Defendant_Behavior: Absence from Canada for extended period due to family obligations
Grounds_for_Claim: Temporary absences justified by familial duty and maintenance of strong ties to Canada
Legal_Standard: Three years of residence in Canada within four years before application; liberal interpretation if ties are maintained
Assessment_Factor: Duration of absence, reasons for absence, strength of ties to Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Chan's evidence regarding care for mother and ongoing ties to Canada deemed credible
Evidence_Used: Proof of businesses in Canada, family connections, community involvement, travel records, documentation of mother's illness
Evidence_Assessed: Travel history, personal and financial ties to Canada, purpose and temporary nature of absences
Governing_Rule: Residency requirement interpreted liberally where absences are temporary and ties to Canada are maintained
Outcome: Appeal granted; Mr. Chan satisfies residency requirements
Harm_Assessment: Denial of citizenship due to alleged failure to meet residency
Cause_Description: Mr. Chan's application for Canadian citizenship was denied due to insufficient physical presence
Evidence_Handling: Evidence of Canadian ties and justification for absence accepted and weighed in favor of applicant
Legal_Provision_Violated: None found; requirement satisfied despite absence
Residency_Compliance: Compliant with residency requirement under liberal interpretation
Evidence_Assessment: Positive assessment of evidence supporting temporary absence and strong Canadian ties
Decision_Rationale: Absences were temporary and justified; significant ties to Canada maintained
Legal_Standard_Applied: Liberal interpretation of residency requirement considering ties to Canada and temporary nature of absences
